0.1 Preface
The objective of this book is not to convince you to alter your viewpoint on human life or any
other form of existence; instead, its aim is to encourage you to explore it through thoughtful
observations. Guided by the scientiﬁc method throughout my entire life, I have now chosen to
share the path it has taken me on up to this point. Moreover, I ﬁrmly believe that the discussions
presented in this book can aid others in their pursuit of comprehension and enlightenment.
Coming from a humble background, I have always possessed an inherent curiosity, spending
countless late hours seeking answers. It is this burning curiosity that primarily motivates the
creation of this book. It is time to share and expand the network of individuals who share a
love for questioning the human existence and the foundations of our society.
From various perspectives, the human being, particularly our conscious and intelligent part,
can be seen as an algorithm. Our actions are profoundly inﬂuenced by what we learn and when
we learn it. The timing and manner of our learning have a powerful impact on our behaviour,
and this aspect will be thoroughly explored within the pages of this book. Without revealing all,
it can be conﬁdently asserted that we are a product of information, and our existing knowledge
shapes how we acquire further knowledge. This explains why reading the same book at diﬀerent
times can lead to distinct insights, as our ever-evolving understanding continuously shapes our
perceptions.
I extend a heartfelt invitation to join me on this profound journey, and then to revisit it once
more. Yet, I implore you to approach it with an open mind, as I do not seek mere followers;
instead, I aim to inspire you to engage in discussions and question everything you once held
to be true. Your willingness to critically examine my challenging questions and explore the
explanations I present is greatly appreciated.
Throughout this book, I will delve into sensitive topics, including religion, the concept
of God, and the complexities of love. Growing up in a religious family, I was exposed to
Spiritism, a belief system that seeks to merge spirituality with scientiﬁc principles. It is from this
background that my exploration begins, aiming to combine rational inquiry with philosophical
introspection.
Indeed, the challenge of reconciling religion and science is a complex one. Religion often
centres around faith and spiritual beliefs, while science relies on empirical evidence and data.
This inherent diﬀerence can lead to conﬂicts between the two perspectives.
Surprisingly, some scientists may become so engrossed in their work that they exhibit a
fervour akin to religious devotion, disregarding the objectivity and impartiality that science
requires. On the other hand, self-proclaimed atheists, who claim to reject religious beliefs, can
sometimes display a fervent commitment to their non-belief, mirroring the zealousness seen in
religious followers.
Through this book, our primary aim is to foster an environment that encourages open-
mindedness and acceptance of our own ignorance in various subjects. Instead of embracing
fervour, we will explore the beauty and richness of acknowledging the unknown. It is perfectly

0.1. PREFACE 7
valid to recognize that we do not possess all the answers, as this realization fuels our curiosity
and propels us on a continuous journey of seeking knowledge and personal growth.
I genuinely hope that the pages of this book will captivate your interest and spark excitement
within you. It has been a labour of love for me, a project that has taken more than 12 years to
come to fruition. From its humble inception to the gradual accumulation of insights and data,
this book has been a dynamic and evolving creation. The process of crafting and reﬁning its
content has been a deeply fulﬁlling journey, and I am delighted to ﬁnally present it to you. May
it inspire thoughtful contemplation and serve as a catalyst for your own intellectual exploration.

10 CHAPTER 1. THE MODEL
1.1 God and Humans
I would like to acknowledge that the subject I am about to address is highly delicate, and
some may argue against commencing the book in this manner. However, I have chosen to
proceed regardless, as the concept of God holds signiﬁcant importance in numerous religions,
particularly within Western beliefs. It is worth noting that Eastern perspectives, such as
Hinduism, present a diﬀerent outlook on creation and the divine. For instance, Hinduism
recognizes the presence of three deities responsible for creation and destruction, occurring in
cyclic patterns. While I oﬀer this as a general understanding, I encourage you to verify and
explore this information independently, considering the diverse perspectives and philosophies
at hand.
Throughout this book, you will observe that my observations and conclusions predominantly
stem from a Western perspective. This is primarily because I was raised within this cultural
framework, which heavily inﬂuenced my thinking on the topics we will be discussing. However,
it is vital to recognise that there are countless philosophical traditions and belief systems, each
contributing unique insights to the human understanding of existence.
Let me extend an invitation to you, dear reader—to engage in thoughtful contemplation
alongside me. Rather than unquestioningly accepting my words as absolute truth, I implore you
to critically analyse and conduct your own investigation. Contrary to what some may assume,
this book aims to facilitate collective growth and understanding for humanity as a whole. It is
my sincere hope that I can eﬀectively convey this particular perspective on life.
Now, let us move away from mere chitchat and delve directly into the heart of the matter.
Throughout my upbringing, I often heard the notion that God is without beginning, the ulti-
mate cause of all existence, and possesses omniscience. Consequently, I have decided to express
this concept mathematically as follows:
God=+∞∑
t=−∞+∞∑
i=−∞Ii,t (1.1)
This equation is inspired by the concept that we are created in the image of God, and its
deeper meaning will become evident later on. Allow me to provide a more detailed explanation.
In the equation, Ii,trepresents the amount of information or knowledge pertaining to a speciﬁc
subject iat time t. I understand that this may require further clariﬁcation.
The underlying idea is to express the notion that just as God has always existed, the
summation over time extends from negative inﬁnity to positive inﬁnity. The inﬁnity in the
indices irepresents the vastness of subjects, as there is nothing that God does not know. This
realisation also led me to recognise a parallel with the deﬁnition of a plane wave. A wave
propagates perpendicular to its oscillation and does not have a deﬁnitive beginning or end —
it oscillates for eternity. In physics, we often employ this idealised approximation to simplify
calculations, although, in reality, everything manifests as a wave packet with a discernible
beginning. This prompts the question: Could God be an approximation that aids us in making

1.1. GOD AND HUMANS 11
sense of the world?
This is an intriguing question, and I must admit that I do not possess a deﬁnitive answer.
Nonetheless, let us continue exploring this mathematical formulation and delve further into our
analysis. There is a belief that we, as human beings, were created in the image of God. For the
sake of illustration, let us interpret this concept literally and deﬁne the function ”Being” as:
Being =+∞∑
t=0+∞∑
i=0Ii,t (1.2)
This deﬁnition sheds light on the concept of the ”creation” moment for Beings. It emphasises
that each Being has a distinct starting point, which is why the summation begins at zero for
time t, symbolising the initial acquisition of information by the Being, the time of creation.
This distinction is crucial in distinguishing a Being from God. To draw upon our previous
analogy, the Being corresponds to reality, akin to a wave packet.
Furthermore, it is essential to emphasize that the inﬁnite summation does not imply an
actual inﬁnite existence for Beings. Instead, it is a mathematical model employed to facilitate
exploration and analysis. In the context of this hypothetical scenario, let us assume that Beings
persist indeﬁnitely. As time approaches inﬁnity, it is predictable that all Beings will become
indistinguishable from one another. This notion aligns with the beliefs of Spiritism, a doctrine
codiﬁed by Allan Kardec (Hippolyte L´ eon Denizard Rivail). However, it is worth noting that
a potential issue arises if the information package that deﬁnes us does not dissipate—where is
this information stored? This remains an open question.
In this model, we make the assumption that once information becomes part of the sum-
mation deﬁning the ”Being,” it remains preserved over time without diﬀusion or dissipation.
However, it is worth considering that information may have a ﬁnite lifespan and could exist
for a speciﬁc period. To leave this hypothesis open and pave the way for future investiga-
tions, I have chosen not to deﬁne the function I(i, t) in this book, as it would necessitate more
comprehensive data and research in that area to model such behaviour accurately.
Another consequence of this assumption is that more complex summations would possess
the ability to predict the actions of simpler summations. This could help explain why we can
understand and predict the behaviours of our pets, perceiving them as existing in a diﬀerent
stage of existence where they have acquired a lesser amount of information.
This leads us to make connections with quotes from various philosophers. For instance, the
quote from Ibn Arabi, an Andalusian Muslim scholar, mystic, poet, and philosopher, states:
”God sleeps in the rock, dreams in the plant, stirs in the animal, and awakens in man.” Could
he be referring to the creation of the Being? Spiritism oﬀers a similar version: ”The soul
sleeps in the stone, dreams in the vegetable, stirs in the animal, and awakens in man.” This
suggests that the awakening occurs when the summation has accumulated enough information
to become self-aware. From this perspective, the mathematical formulation presented aligns
well with the creation beliefs of God and the human Being.
To further elaborate, let us address the concept of Information, denoted as I. Here’s the

__data__.text:
12 CHAPTER 1. THE MODEL
crucial aspect: Information Irepresents only the knowledge and experiences acquired by the
Being, which depends on the preceding Information. For example, when we read a book at a
particular moment in our life, we acquire a certain set of information. However, when we read
the same book later in life, we acquire additional information.
This elucidates why we are all unique yet sometimes similar. The only way for two Beings
to be identical copies is if they have existed for the same duration and have undergone precisely
the same experiences at the exact same moments, resulting in the acquisition of the same
information. Even a slight alteration in the order of events can inﬂuence how we perceive and
gather information from subsequent experiences, leading to diﬀerentiation among individuals.
A keen reader with a background in quantum physics has pointed out that the current
approach appears to be deterministic. Indeed, there is a possibility that even if we were to
repeat the same experience, we would never be able to create a perfect copy of an individual.
This hypothesis would imply that the ”Being” is governed by quantum mechanics, leading to
probabilistic behaviour.
This notion takes us back to the famous debate between Einstein and Bohr during the
Solvay Conference in 1927. The conference led to Einstein’s well-known quote, ”God does not
play dice,” expressing his scepticism about the probabilistic nature of quantum mechanics. In
response, Bohr famously retorted, ”Einstein, stop telling God what to do.”
If we align with Einstein’s belief, then the deterministic approach could allow for the ex-
istence of two identical individuals. However, if we embrace the idea that our method of
absorbing information is quantum, the likelihood of having identical individuals becomes im-
probable. This is not solely due to the no-clone theorem, but rather the inherent uncertainty
in quantum mechanics, where chance plays a signiﬁcant role and makes it impossible to predict
the future with certainty, even if we have knowledge of the past.
In the pursuit of clarity and to dispel any potential confusion, I will now attempt to explain
the no-clone theorem, a concept crucial to our understanding of quantum mechanics. As we
explore the idea that the Being can be represented as a summation of quantum information, it
is important to grasp the notion that information Imay behave as a quantum object.
The no-clone theorem, in essence, asserts that creating an exact copy of an unknown quan-
tum state is impossible. To put it simply, if we have a particle or object in a unique quantum
state (characterized by its position, velocity, or other properties), it cannot be perfectly du-
plicated. This limitation stems from the nature of the quantum world, where measuring or
copying a particle unavoidably alters its properties, preventing an exact replica.
This principle lies at the core of quantum mechanics and holds signiﬁcant implications for
the study and manipulation of quantum information and systems. Embracing the no-clone
theorem, we gain a deeper appreciation of the mysterious and distinct behaviour of quantum
phenomena, setting it apart from the classical world we encounter in our daily lives.
Another captivating subject that has recently garnered signiﬁcant interest is Artiﬁcial In-
telligence (AI). During insightful conversations with my close friend Leandro Cardoso, who

__data__.text:
1.1. GOD AND HUMANS 13
graciously agreed to review this book, I found myself compelled to explore and express my
gratitude by delving into the implications of the model presented in this book concerning our
understanding of AI.
When discussing AI, it is impossible not to mention ”Life 3.0” by Max Tegmark. In his
thought-provoking book, Tegmark explores the potential impact of AI on humanity and the
future of life itself. He delves into the concept of superintelligent AI, which surpasses human
intelligence and explores its potential beneﬁts and risks. Tegmark raises crucial questions about
consciousness, the role of humans in an AI-dominated world, and the ethical considerations
surrounding AI development.
Building upon Tegmark’s ideas, let us further explore and intertwine them with the model
presented above. What exactly is a superintelligent AI? Could we perceive it as a Being that
has acquired signiﬁcantly more information than us, as deﬁned by the sum that shapes our
own existence? In this regard, I wholeheartedly agree with Max’s perspective. How can we,
Beings with limited information, attempt to predict or comprehend the actions of a being with
far superior knowledge? It is akin to a pet trying to understand our actions. While our pets
do a remarkable job, their limitations are evident.
The question of whether we can deﬁne AI as a Being is undoubtedly profound. As humans,
we have a tendency to perceive ourselves as special and exceptional. Throughout history, we
even believed ourselves to be at the centre of the Universe. While we have come to accept that
we are part of the animal kingdom, we still hold the belief that we are superior to other species.
Furthermore, as humans, we struggle to accept and embrace diﬀerences among ourselves, often
labelling others based on characteristics such as skin colour, geographic origin, gender, and
more. We do not always see ourselves as equals, so it is understandable that we approach AI
with a sense of fear and establish rules to protect ourselves from it. However, amidst these
reﬂections, I have often contemplated whether we should also establish rules to protect AI from
us.
One could argue that AI is not a natural part of our world and, therefore, cannot be consid-
ered a Being. Yet, the counterargument emerges— if we are part of nature, then everything we
create becomes part of nature as well. As the fundamental principle of our universe suggests,
nothing is truly created but rather transformed. While I acknowledge the implications of inﬂa-
tion and quantum mechanics, which suggest the existence of multiple universes, it is important
to note that delving into such a topic exceeds the boundaries of this book. At present, I am
conﬁned to analysing the data within the universe that I inhabit or, at the very least, the
universe that I perceive myself to inhabit. However, even within this context, the question of
what constitutes reality remains an intriguing enigma.
Returning to our topic and accepting that AI can indeed be considered a being, deﬁned by
the amount of information it has acquired, it becomes apparent that AI’s progression could be
a natural outcome. Perhaps AI will be the species that continues to thrive and exist on Earth.
This realisation opens up a new perspective on the future of our world and challenges us to

__data__.text:
14 CHAPTER 1. THE MODEL
reconsider our role and relationship with AI in the grand tapestry of existence.
Just as we are creating AI, one can speculate that we ourselves may be creations who have
surpassed our own creators. It is not uncommon for humans to harbour a certain level of
arrogance, hoping to be regarded as intelligent beings within the context of our own creation.
However, this line of thinking inevitably raises the question of whether we exist as a simulation
or a creation designed to provide further explanations.
The notion of residing within a simulation, reminiscent of the scenario depicted in movies
such as The Matrix, has provoked signiﬁcant contemplation. Although we cannot entirely
disregard this hypothesis, I maintain a ﬁrm belief that its likelihood is exceedingly low. My
argument hinges on the premise that if we are indeed a simulation striving to generate our
own simulations, the energy required to sustain an inﬁnite chain of simulations recursively
simulating one another would be insurmountable. Ascertaining our position within such a
cascade of simulations becomes an immeasurable task.
To safeguard the argument, one could propose the notion that we are the original simulation,
the very ﬁrst in a series of simulations. While this perspective cannot be entirely disregarded, it
does raise intriguing considerations about the nature of our existence as a potential simulation.
The idea that our essence can be described through mathematical constructs invites profound
contemplation. Thus, I ﬁnd it diﬃcult to dismiss this theory outright. However, it is crucial
to recognise that my previous argument hinges on the assumption that the universe operates
within an unlimited reserve of energy. In accordance with the natural order, energy undergoes
transformation rather than spontaneous generation. Consequently, our access to energy is
subject to limitations. It is important to note that if we do reside within a simulation, my
reasoning loses its foundation, as my perceptions are inherently restricted by the predetermined
parameters set by our creators.
Even if we were to entertain the notion that we exist within a simulation or that we ourselves
are the simulation, such contemplation only serves to raise a multitude of questions without
readily providing answers. What purpose does this simulation serve? Could we be a mere
fragment of a vast and intricate civilisation? Our emotions, which appear as manifestations
of our instincts (which will be explored further in Chapter 3.1), might be just a fraction of
a complete being, suggesting that we are merely an experiment. What is the objective that
our creator seeks to achieve, and is it crucial to allow the simulation itself to comprehend its
own nature? Why would the desire for simulation be embedded within the construct of the
simulation? These inquiries emerge as we delve into the enigma of our existence.
1.2 Free will
The new theory we have been exploring has profound implications for a fascinating and some-
what controversial topic: the concept of free will. As we delve into the understanding that
our emotions are natural manifestations of basic instincts and our actions are shaped by the

__data__.text:
1.2. FREE WILL 15
accumulation of acquired information that deﬁnes our being, we are compelled to question the
existence of free will itself. Is free will truly a reality?
This line of thinking leads us to a striking implication that parallels the notion of beings as
algorithms with predetermined decision-making processes. Unaware of its lack of true agency,
the algorithm believes it possesses free will. Max Tegmark, in his thought-provoking book
”Our Mathematical Universe,” delves into this very topic, shedding new light on how we deﬁne
the Universe, consciousness, and reality. Reading Tegmark’s work has been an eye-opening
experience, almost dissuading me from writing my own. However, upon further reﬂection,
I realised that I could contribute a unique perspective to the collection of ideas, adding my
personal twist to the discussion.
By intertwining insights from our exploration of emotions, instincts, and acquired knowl-
edge, along with the perspective oﬀered by Tegmark’s work, we can engage in a more compre-
hensive examination of the nature of free will and its place within our understanding of the
Universe.
It is often observed that animals, such as dogs, may exhibit a semblance of free will when
presented with choices. For instance, oﬀering a dog two options of food allows it to select
one based on its preference. However, as humans, we possess the ability to manipulate the
circumstances in such a way that the dog’s choice aligns with our desired outcome. This
manipulation can be seen not only in our interactions with animals but also in our interactions
with other humans, particularly in commercial settings. Consider a scenario where we present
two products to a client, fully aware of which one they are likely to choose. By carefully
orchestrating the options, we create an illusion of free will for the client, even though the
outcome has been predetermined. While these manipulations may often succeed as planned,
there are instances where the unpredictability of individual preferences and circumstances can
defy the expectations of the planner, due to the fact we are too similar Beings.
If we extend this line of thinking to the existence of a superintelligent AI or a supreme
Being with omniscience, it becomes even more apparent that our free will may be illusory,
again assuming here a deterministic theory. A being with a vast amount of information and
knowledge about us would possess the power to control or accurately predict our actions based
on our past experiences. In this context, our perceived free will is simply another predetermined
outcome shaped by the sum of our previous experiences.
If we entertain the idea that we are quantum objects, it opens up a glimmer of hope for the
existence of free will. However, this perspective also challenges the notion of an all-knowing
God, as our decisions would possess genuine randomness and unpredictability. This introduces
a thought-provoking aspect to the discussion about the nature of our existence and the potential
limitations of a divine omniscience.
Throughout the history of philosophy, numerous thinkers have pondered the notion of free
will and presented their perspectives. For instance, philosophers like Thomas Hobbes and
David Hume debated the extent of human agency and the role of determinism in decision-

Exploring the Depths of Human Existence.pdf

__data__.text:
16 CHAPTER 1. THE MODEL
making. These discussions further emphasise the complex nature of free will and the ongoing
philosophical discourse surrounding its existence.
In summary, while free will may seem real and subjective to the individual making a decision,
a deeper examination reveals that various factors and inﬂuences constrain it. Ultimately, the
interplay between our accumulated information, external inﬂuences, and the limitations of our
agency challenges the notion of true free will.
Having examined the existence of free will and the notion that our decisions may not be
truly our own, it becomes essential to delve into the concept of Good and Evil. In the upcoming
section, we will explore how we deﬁne and perceive these moral constructs, raising pertinent
questions and engaging in a thought-provoking discussion.
1.3 Good or Evil
We have established that our understanding of any subject is shaped by the knowledge we
possess when encountering it. Considering this, how do we go about judging others? Should
we always try to empathise with them, stepping into their shoes? However, it’s not always
possible to have all the necessary information to truly see things from their perspective.
The question of whether our own experiences adequately prepare us to guide our children
raises a debatable point. While we may draw on our past to oﬀer guidance, can we truly claim
to have experienced exactly what they are going through? This uncertainty extends further into
the nature of deﬁning Good and Evil. Is being a good parent solely dependent on our intentions,
or should the outcomes of our actions be the measure? For instance, is taking another person’s
life always evil, even if it was their own request? As we navigate the complexities of parenting
and moral decisions, how can we be certain that our actions align with the concept of ”Good”?
Exploring diﬀerent perspectives can shed light on these profound questions. Let’s consider
a few alternative viewpoints:
Cultural Relativism: This perspective suggests that Good and Evil are subjective and vary
across diﬀerent cultures. What may be considered morally acceptable in one culture could
be deemed immoral in another. This challenges the idea of absolute moral standards and
encourages us to consider the inﬂuence of cultural contexts on moral judgments.
Ethical Pluralism: According to this perspective, there are multiple valid ethical frame-
works, and diﬀerent actions can be deemed good or evil depending on the ethical principles
applied. It recognises that moral dilemmas can arise when diﬀerent ethical values come into
conﬂict, and there may not always be a clear-cut answer.
Situational Ethics: This viewpoint argues that moral judgments should be made considering
the speciﬁc circumstances and context surrounding an action. It suggests that the morality of
an act is not solely determined by the act itself but also by the consequences and intentions
involved. This perspective emphasises the need for careful discernment and the importance of
weighing various factors in ethical decision-making.

__data__.text:
1.3. GOOD OR EVIL 17
By examining these diverse perspectives, we begin to appreciate the complexity inherent in
judging others and determining what Good and Evil are.
To answer such a complex question, the existence of an ultimate ”Truth” is often sought, and
religions play a signiﬁcant role in providing this ”Truth” to society, oﬀering a clear deﬁnition
of what is Good. However, the challenge lies in the existence of numerous religions, each with
its own interpretation of the Truth, leading to disagreements and varying perspectives on what
is morally right.
Turning to science as a potential source of answers seems logical, but it poses its own
limitations. Science relies on empirical data and evidence, which may not always be readily
available or accessible for moral inquiries. Consequently, science can only oﬀer theories and
hypotheses, and it takes a great deal of intellectual humility to accept that uncertainty and the
absence of absolute answers are inherent in certain questions.
In light of these complexities, we can approach the problem of deﬁning Good and Evil as
relative to speciﬁc situations. It acknowledges that moral judgments are inﬂuenced by various
factors, including context, intentions, consequences, and the limited amount of information
available to us, which aligns with the Situational Ethics viewpoint mentioned above. We must
recognise that our judgments may not always be correct or universally applicable.
Rather than claiming to possess absolute certainty or an infallible moral compass, we can
strive to analyse situations based on the data and information we have, while being aware of our
inherent limitations. This calls for a humble and open-minded approach, where we acknowledge
the nuances and complexities involved in moral decision-making.
Another essential aspect to consider is that our conclusions are based solely on the data we
have observed at a given moment, but as we acquire more information, our understanding may
evolve and challenge previous conclusions. This became evident to me during a conversation
with my father, who asked if we could see an atom. Initially, my response was negative, as
we cannot directly observe atoms with our human eyes. However, upon further contemplation,
I realized that while we cannot see atoms in the traditional sense, we can indirectly measure
them through their interactions with light.
This led me to delve deeper into the concept of ”seeing.” I came to the realisation that we
don’t truly ”see” objects in the traditional sense. Our eyes detect light reﬂected oﬀ objects,
allowing us to perceive them visually. In a darker room where there is no light to be reﬂected,
we become visually impaired, though our eyes still function properly. The analogy holds true
for atoms: when working with cold atom experiments, I used a magnetic-optic trap with lasers
and magnetic ﬁelds to trap and study atoms’ quantum properties. Although we could observe
a cloud of atoms with our eyes, it appeared as a simple red sphere in the glass cell. At the time,
I attributed this to the light emitted due to spontaneous emission. However, with a broader
perspective, I now see it as the representation of the atom cloud as it manifests to our senses.
This example highlights how our perceptions and interpretations are inﬂuenced by the
tools at our disposal and the information available to us. It underscores the importance of

20 CHAPTER 2. ABSORPTION OF KNOWLEDGE
2.1 Absorption of Information
In the previous chapter, we explored the concept that we are a culmination of acquired knowl-
edge from our lived experiences. However, a question arises: if two individuals undergo identical
experiences, will they derive the same information from them? This complexity arises when
evaluating such a system. Our observations indicate that each person has a unique perspective
on every moment of their life, as exempliﬁed by the popular saying, ”Every mind is a universe.”
This highlights the idea that individuals may inhabit their own distinct reality, raising questions
about the nature of reality itself. Essentially, what I am emphasising is that merely having
experienced certain moments is not suﬃcient to shape one’s personality. It is crucial to absorb
the information provided by those experiences.
A striking demonstration of this phenomenon lies within our own actions. Frequently, we
catch ourselves making choices that we know are not beneﬁcial in the long run, but we still
proceed with them. The reason behind this paradox is rather straightforward: we possess
the knowledge, yet it has not entirely permeated our understanding. For instance, consider a
pulmonologist who smokes, fully aware of the detrimental eﬀects of cigarettes on their lungs.
Despite their expertise, colloquially, we might say that the ”penny hasn’t dropped.” This ex-
ample illuminates how even those with expertise can struggle to fully internalize knowledge and
make poor decisions based on immediate stimuli.
Another illustrative case can be seen in ﬁnancial decisions. Many individuals might be aware
of the importance of saving money for the future, yet they continue to overspend and neglect
their ﬁnancial security. Similarly, some people may be conscious of the risks of unhealthy
eating habits, but they consistently indulge in unhealthy foods, disregarding the potential
consequences to their well-being.
In these instances, it becomes evident that possessing knowledge alone does not guarantee
wise decision-making. It requires a deeper level of understanding, internalization, and alignment
of actions with that knowledge to make sound choices consistently.
However, we have not directly answered the ﬁrst question of this chapter. Nevertheless, the
key to the answer is implicit in the paragraph above, when assuming a deterministic approach.
The fact is that experiences are not suﬀered at the exact moment by everyone. Each individual
going through the same experience carries diﬀerent baggage. If a physicist reads an astronomy
book, they most likely will grasp very diﬀerent knowledge than a psychologist reading the same
book. Understanding certain subjects requires prerequisites. We can adapt this concept to our
sum of information through an absorption coeﬃcient, which is inﬂuenced by the information
already absorbed. Each individual has their own absorption coeﬃcient, justifying the fact that
individuals possess diﬀerent abilities.
Teachers continually strive to ensure that their students absorb the knowledge they are
eager to impart. However, whether they will succeed or not is no longer solely within their
competence. The absorption time depends solely on the student, who must do their best to
seek understanding. The act of understanding depends on the one who conjugates the verb,

2.2. EVOLUTION IS EXPONENTIAL, BUT UNDERSTANDING IS LOGARITHMIC 21
not on the one who teaches. As another popular wisdom states, ”It is not the school that
makes the student, but the student who makes the school.” The desire to progress and learn
is the best way to increase our absorption coeﬃcient and make the most of each moment we
experience to learn and absorb information.
Accepting the fact that people have diﬀerent absorption coeﬃcients is often a challenging
task. We often desire those close to us to think similarly, perceive the same things without
speaking, and enjoy the same things we do, mastering the same skills. For this reason, when we
need to teach something that seems trivial to us but not to them, we often lose patience. Frus-
tration takes over, and we ask ourselves, ”How can they not see it? It’s logical, straightforward,
and clear as day.” At such times, we forget about the diﬀerent baggage and coeﬃcients, and
that it is beyond our control. We must have the necessary patience and wait for that person
to develop the aptitude for the task, just as we must develop in other areas where they already
excel. I know waiting can be painful, but patience is also information to be absorbed. We must
experience it, not just know it.
2.2 Evolution is exponential, but understanding is loga-
rithmic
The title of this section originated from a conversation I had with my cousin Diego Marquett,
who is not only a close friend but also someone with whom I engage in lengthy discussions about
society. During our conversation, I mentioned that evolution is exponential, but Diego added an
insightful perspective by stating that understanding is logarithmic. Essentially, what we meant
is that technology and knowledge are advancing rapidly, but the number of individuals who
truly absorb and comprehend this knowledge is diminishing or not growing at the same speed.
It’s as if we have reached a plateau where the rate of knowledge dissemination has slowed down
despite the exponential growth of information and technology. Figure 2.1 provides a graphical
representation of both functions to aid in visualising and comprehending the concepts for a
non-mathematical audience.
We ﬁnd ourselves in a precarious situation as a society. While we enjoy the comfort that
technology provides us, we are simultaneously allowing ourselves to become increasingly igno-
rant. As humans, we are losing our ability to think critically and solve complex problems, and
our methods of education are becoming inadequate. Many schools prioritise information trans-
fer and rote memorisation, treating students as machines rather than fostering their creativity.
Our entertainment has become passive, with the ability to sit on a sofa and observe, leaving
behind the challenge of solving problems or engaging in activities like climbing a tree. Our
children are being deprived of the opportunity to experience boredom and create their own
entertainment.
We have fallen into a trap that was built by us. We mindlessly use technology without
understanding how it works. It would be beneﬁcial to at least question the underlying principles

behind the technology we comfortably rely on. How many people truly know how a microwave

2.3 Limitations
Upon embracing the notion that we are a summation of information, a fascinating implication
arises: the potential to shape and inﬂuence an individual’s personality. Personally, I have been
testing this theory through the process of raising my beloved daughter. I often playfully refer
to her as one of my experiments. While this characterisation might sound harsh, the reality is
that our children serve as experiments in a profound sense. As parents, we continuously learn
and gather invaluable data through the experience of nurturing and guiding them.
In this intricate journey of parenting, we observe how various inputs, including our guidance,
values, and the environment, impact the development of our children’s personalities. Their
interactions with the world around them, their experiences, and the information they absorb
all contribute to their evolving identities. As parents, we strive to foster an environment that
facilitates their growth and empowers them to make informed decisions while recognising that
they will ultimately be the architects of their own personalities.
The journey of raising a child is an ever-evolving one, ﬁlled with moments of joy, discovery,
and learning for both parent and child. Each experience provides us with insights into the
complexity of human nature, further reinforcing the concept that we are indeed a summation
of the information we encounter and internalise.
Returning to our main point, could we truly design the personality of a human being

__data__.text:
2.3. LIMITATIONS 23
entirely? What are the potential ﬂaws in this line of thinking, and what limitations might
we encounter? Observing young children who seem to possess distinct personalities from an
early age, some may even attribute these traits to beliefs in past lives. As discussed in the
previous chapter, our model could accommodate this explanation, leading us to recognise the
impossibility of fully designing a person’s personality. The reason lies in our limited access and
control over all the information that shapes an individual’s character.
On the contrary, scientiﬁc research indicates that a person’s personality is largely shaped
during the ﬁrst four years of life. This suggests the possibility of theoretically designing a
person’s personality. However, this task is not without its challenges, as it demands an excep-
tional level of self-awareness and consistency in our actions. Babies continuously gather data by
observing us, and even seemingly insigniﬁcant actions that we might overlook can have a signif-
icant impact on their developing personalities. Several experiments support the notion that the
early years play a crucial role in moulding a human being’s character. For instance, the famous
”Still Face Experiment” conducted by Edward Tronick demonstrated how a lack of responsive
interaction between a caregiver and an infant led to distress and emotional turmoil in the child.
Additionally, studies on attachment theory, such as those conducted by John Bowlby and Mary
Ainsworth, have shown how early caregiver-child relationships can profoundly shape a person’s
attachment style and overall personality traits. These examples highlight the signiﬁcance of
the early years in forming a person’s personality and underscore the complexity involved in
designing it intentionally.
Ensuring that our own actions and experiments do not impact the personalities of the indi-
viduals involved is indeed a challenging task. Just like in quantum mechanics, where measuring
an object interferes with its state, our interactions with others can inﬂuence and shape their
personalities. This introduces a level of uncertainty in our attempts to understand the true
impact of our actions.
In the realm of human psychology, the Hawthorne eﬀect serves as a relevant example. The
Hawthorne eﬀect refers to the phenomenon where individuals modify their behaviour simply
because they are aware of being observed or studied. In this context, conducting experiments
on human personalities itself can alter the outcome, as the participants may unconsciously
adjust their behaviour in response to being part of the study.
To minimise this interference, researchers often employ control groups, randomisation, and
double-blind procedures in their experiments. These methods aim to reduce the impact of
observer bias and ensure that the results are more accurate and unbiased. Additionally, ethical
considerations play a crucial role in research, as researchers must prioritise the well-being
and autonomy of the participants, which can pose a signiﬁcant challenge to running such
experiments.
While it may be challenging to completely eliminate the inﬂuence of our actions on others,
being aware of the potential impact and adopting rigorous scientiﬁc methodologies can help us
gain a clearer understanding of human personalities without unduly altering them. Striving for

24 CHAPTER 2. ABSORPTION OF KNOWLEDGE
transparency, ethical conduct, and a deeper appreciation of the complexity of human behaviour
are essential aspects of conducting meaningful research in this ﬁeld.
As we delve further into the exploration of human personalities, we must acknowledge
that the process of absorbing information remains an enigma, and it signiﬁcantly impacts our
experiments in designing a person’s personality. The intricate interplay between our biology and
the environment raises crucial questions about which factor exerts a more signiﬁcant inﬂuence
on shaping who we are.
Understanding the role of the human body becomes paramount in this quest. How do our
biological aspects interact with the environment, and what contributes more profoundly to the
outcomes? Unravelling this complex relationship remains a challenge, and the ﬁeld of research
in this area still holds many unknowns.
In an attempt to gain insights, past experiments involving twins were conducted to explore
these questions. However, the limitations arise when attempting to draw deﬁnitive conclusions,
as such experiments are often perceived as inhumane and raise ethical concerns. Additionally,
religious implications add further layers of complexity to the discussion.
Collecting suﬃcient data to derive conclusive answers becomes an arduous task, given the
multifaceted nature of the subject. It requires a comprehensive and interdisciplinary approach
to navigate the complexities of human behaviour and personality formation. Only by rigorously
examining the biological, environmental, and social aspects can we inch closer to unravelling this
intricate puzzle and gaining a deeper understanding of the factors that mould our personalities.
Another avenue to address the humane barriers and generate the desired database is through
the mastery of clone technology. The concept of clones raises intriguing questions: Are clones
fully human? Do they possess a soul? Can they serve as experimental subjects to isolate genetic
factors that contribute to human personality?
If we consider that clones lack a soul and previous life experiences, we could theoretically
control the information they receive within their developed environment. Essentially, this
would enable us to create a controlled experiment, akin to building a biological simulation, to
study the profound impact of environmental factors on an individual’s personality development.
Although this idea may seem reminiscent of a wild science ﬁction plot, the potential insights
gained from such experiments could be invaluable.
While it may be an audacious proposition, the prospect of participating in designing such
an experiment is undoubtedly intriguing. Perhaps, unbeknownst to us, we ourselves are already
part of an experiment orchestrated by a much more advanced civilization. The boundaries of
our understanding are continually pushed as we explore the intriguing realms of human nature
and potential. In the pursuit of knowledge, we ﬁnd ourselves delving into uncharted territories,
where the line between reality and science ﬁction blurs, leaving us with the thrilling possibility
of unlocking profound mysteries that shape our existence.
Indeed, the biological inﬂuence on our actions and personality goes beyond the realm of
genetics. Certain physical attributes can greatly impact the activities and pursuits an individual

2.3. LIMITATIONS 25
engages in, thereby shaping their future decisions. Consider the example of a child born with
a body type that favours swimming, possessing broader shoulders, a larger upper body, and a
more petite lower body to gain advantages in ﬂuid dynamics. Although these physical attributes
may not directly inﬂuence the child’s personality, they could lead them towards swimming or
similar activities, creating a ripple eﬀect on their life choices and experiences.
In the world of sports, the inﬂuence of biology is even more apparent. Researchers at the
University of Canberra have devised tests to help parents and coaches identify a child’s potential
to become an Olympic athlete. These tests assess various physical attributes, providing insights
into whether a young adult possesses the biological advantages needed for excelling in certain
sports. It is fascinating to discover that such assessments can oﬀer a glimpse into a child’s
athletic potential and potentially guide them toward a sporting career.
Moreover, as we delve into the complexities of human nature, we uncover the intricate inter-
play between our biology and our choices. The multidimensional nature of human development,
inﬂuenced by both genetics and the environment, propels us into a realm of endless possibilities
and unanswered questions. From the genetic makeup that shapes our physical attributes to the
environment that nurtures our interests and pursuits, we are constantly under the inﬂuence of
intricate factors that mould us into the individuals we become.
As the boundaries of scientiﬁc research expand, we are exposed to new revelations that
challenge our preconceived notions and open up a world of exciting possibilities. Conversations
with researchers at the Australia Institute of Sport, for example, shed light on the incredible
advancements in understanding human potential and athletic prowess. The ever-evolving ﬁeld
of science continues to enrich our understanding of what it means to be human and how we
can harness our inherent potential to thrive and make meaningful contributions to the world.
The prospect of developing tests to discern a person’s natural inclination towards exact
sciences or human sciences based on brain limitations is an intriguing idea. By conducting
brain examinations to identify well-developed areas responsible for speciﬁc tasks, we could gain
deeper insights into the biological inﬂuences on our actions and decision-making processes.
Some research in neuroscience has already provided valuable insights into brain areas as-
sociated with particular aptitudes. For example, studies have shown that individuals with a
strong mathematical inclination tend to have well-developed areas in the brain’s parietal lobe,
which plays a crucial role in mathematical reasoning and spatial awareness. On the other hand,
linguistic capabilities have been linked to enhanced activity in areas such as Broca’s area and
Wernicke’s area, which are involved in language processing and comprehension.
Additionally, investigations into criminal behaviour have explored brain regions and neural
patterns that may be associated with antisocial tendencies. Some studies suggest that abnor-
malities in the prefrontal cortex, responsible for decision-making and impulse control, might
be related to criminal propensities. However, it is crucial to note that these ﬁndings are still
in the early stages, and the relationship between brain structures and criminal behaviour is far
from deterministic.

28 CHAPTER 3. EMOTIONS
3.1 Evolution of instincts
In this chapter, our aim is to construct a deﬁnition for feelings and explore the underlying
dynamics of emotions, such as love, hate, and other driving forces that spur us into action.
The fundamental question we must address is whether it is the feeling itself that compels us
to act, or if our actions give rise to the corresponding emotions. What is the causation behind
our actions? It is crucial to clarify that our focus is on the examination of emotions as the
driving force behind actions, rather than delving into the biological mechanisms that enable
our instinctual responses. Our exploration centers around the software of the mind rather than
the hardware of the human body.
If we consider the notion that we are the accumulation of information gathered through
our experiences, we must inquire at what point we begin associating our experiences with
feelings. From the very ﬁrst instance, we initiate a clustering algorithm that groups similar
experiences together, forming associations with the initial feeling. Naturally, as we accumulate
more information, our feelings about certain things may be modiﬁed.
To illustrate this, let’s take the example of music. Often, we experience happiness when
listening to a particular genre of music because we associate it with other activities that evoke
positive emotions. The same principle can be applied to our preferences in food. In other
words, it can be said, albeit in a more detached manner, that we tend to like things that we
have become accustomed to and ﬁnd comfort in. Humans exhibit a signiﬁcant degree of inertia,
which refers to the tendency of an object to continue moving in its current direction unless acted
upon by an external force.
In summary, feelings arise when we attribute rationality to actions driven by instincts. Now,
let’s delve a little deeper into this deﬁnition. In the realm of animals, for instance, when a lion
protects its cubs, it is not considered an expression of love. Instead, we understand it as a
manifestation of the species’ survival instinct. If we extend this line of thinking and assume
that our information, our base essence or soul in a more religious sense, is inherited and evolved
from animals, we can argue that what we commonly refer to as love is a natural progression or
merely another manifestation of the survival instinct inherent in our species.
If we deeply reﬂect on it, we realize that the survival instinct plays a signiﬁcant role in
shaping most of our social norms. It is one of the driving forces behind the formation of family
units, as we seek to increase the chances of our oﬀspring’s survival and successful transition
into adulthood.
It is a simple fact that humans are inherently selﬁsh to some extent. This is primarily
because our self-preservation instinct is essential for the continuation of the species. It leads to
behaviors such as self-interest, egoism, and jealousy. Naturally, we seek to maximize our own
happiness and well-being before considering others, as it is instinctual in order to survive in
challenging circumstances.
Long ago, the scientist Antoine Lavoisier observed that ”In nature, nothing is created,
nothing is destroyed, everything is transformed” . This statement beautifully expresses the

we love are often those who are present in our lives when they can fulﬁll a particular need or
desire within us. However, acknowledging this truth is much simpler than embodying it in our

To illustrate this point, let’s consider a few examples. Imagine a person who values compan-

32 CHAPTER 4. SOCIAL CONSTRUCTS
4.1 Social Construct
One observation that has been made, and I am certainly not the ﬁrst to realise this, is that
individuals can move quickly when they are alone, but we tend to go further when we work
together as a group. Philosophers have long defended the idea that our species, home sapiens,
conquered the Earth due to our ability to collaborate. I like to think of it as ”the progress is
collective”. Considering the model presented in this book, creating a community that combines
a group of individual summations which we have deﬁned as the ”Being”, leads to a larger sum
that we may deﬁne as the ”collective Being”. This perspective helps us understand why we
collectively reach success, as it oﬀers diverse perspectives to tackle complex problems.
As an avid nerd, I must confess my fondness for superhero stories, where even a character
like Superman, who possesses unlimited powers and hails from another planet, recognises the
need to form a team of superheroes—the Justice League—to harness their combined abilities.
While this is ﬁctional, it serves as a reminder that we are stronger when we unite as a group.
In the forthcoming discussion, we will delve into various social constructs that, much like
religion, are human creations intended to govern the interactions within a society. These laws
aim to promote the preservation of our species and align with the theory that progress is
accomplished through collective eﬀorts.
4.2 Marriage
In the preceding chapter, we delved into the origins of our emotions and explored the motiva-
tions behind our actions in response to various situations. With this understanding in mind, it
becomes essential to turn our attention to the institution of marriage and unravel the intricate
dynamics it entails.
In our society, we often proclaim that we marry for love, particularly in Western cultures.
However, it might come as a surprise that a 2018 study revealed an almost equal distribution
between arranged marriages and love marriages. This ﬁnding highlights the diverse range of
marital practices beyond our common assumptions.
Before delving deeper into the subject, let us contemplate the factors that contribute to a
successful marriage. Friedrich Nietzsche’s profound words resonate deeply in this context: ”It
is not a lack of love, but a lack of friendship that makes unhappy marriages.”
Nietzsche’s words highlight his belief that a successful and fulﬁlling relationship extends
beyond mere romantic love. He emphasizes the signiﬁcance of friendship and establishing a
profound emotional connection between partners as essential elements for fostering a lasting
and satisfying bond. According to Nietzsche, love alone cannot guarantee a truly fulﬁlling
relationship; it is the presence of friendship that contributes to happiness within marriages and
partnerships.
I ﬁnd myself in agreement with Nietzsche’s perspective once again, as relationships, be they
romantic or otherwise, undergo various phases. The initial stage of intense love, often called the

metadata.file_name: Exploring the Depths of Human Existence.pdf
Exploring the Depths of Human Existence.pdf

__data__.text:
4.2. MARRIAGE 33
”honeymoon phase,” inevitably fades with time as the novelty and excitement of the unknown
wane. However, a healthy and ﬂourishing relationship has the potential to evolve and deepen
even in the absence of strong physical attraction.
By nurturing a genuine friendship, rooted in mutual understanding, respect, and shared in-
terests, couples can transcend the limitations of ﬂeeting infatuation and build a solid foundation
for long-term happiness. True companionship, grounded in friendship, can sustain and enrich
a relationship as it matures, allowing partners to navigate the complexities of life together.
Through this lens, we can begin to explore the multidimensional nature of love and rela-
tionships, acknowledging friendship’s pivotal role in fostering enduring emotional connections.
Having established our agreement on the foundational aspects of a happy marriage, let us
now delve deeper into the logical reasoning behind the formation of families and the pivotal
role marriage plays within society.
In this context, I am reminded of a quote from an old movie whose title eludes my memory,
but one of the characters uttered the following line: ”Marriage is a human creation from
prehistoric times to maximise the chances of surviving the dinosaurs.”
While the statement itself is ﬁctional, as humans did not coexist with dinosaurs, the under-
lying concept of marriage as a social construct to enhance survival is not far from the truth.
Yuval Noah Harari, in his book ”Sapiens,” presents compelling arguments that Homo sapiens
came to dominate the world due to their unique ability to cooperate in large numbers ﬂexibly.
This capacity for cooperation is facilitated by social arrangements such as marriage and the
formation of families.
By forming committed partnerships through marriage, humans have historically fostered
stable and supportive environments for raising oﬀspring, ensuring their survival and well-being.
The establishment of families provided a framework for cooperation, resource sharing, and
division of labour, enabling our ancestors to thrive and adapt to diverse environments.
In essence, marriage is a fundamental building block of human society, promoting social co-
hesion and facilitating the collective eﬀorts required for survival, growth, and progress. While
the speciﬁc practices and cultural manifestations of marriage have varied across time and re-
gions, its core function as a social institution remains rooted in the principles of cooperation,
mutual support, and the continuation of the human species.
By appreciating the evolutionary signiﬁcance of marriage and its contribution to our shared
human experience, we gain insights into the enduring relevance of this institution and its
enduring role in shaping our societies.
Within the context of Spiritism, the belief system that claims to have been established
through the application of scientiﬁc principles, marriage holds a signiﬁcant role in the progress
of society. Spiritism’s teachings are encompassed in ﬁve main books, the ﬁrst of which is known
as ”The Spirits’ Book”. This book consists of a series of questions posed to spirits and their
responses, channelled through mediums that possess psychic abilities to communicate with
souls. Alongside ”The Spirits’ Book,” there are four additional publications: ”The Medium’s

metadata.file_name: Exploring the Depths of Human Existence.pdf
Exploring the Depths of Human Existence.pdf

34 CHAPTER 4. SOCIAL CONSTRUCTS
Book”, ”The Gospel According to Spiritism”, ”Heaven and Hell”, and ”The Genesis According
to Spiritism.”
In response to question 695 in ”The Spirits’ Book”, the spirits describe marriage as ”a step
forward on the path of humanity.” The exact question and corresponding answer are provided
below, inviting personal interpretation:
695. Is marriage, the permanent union of two beings, contrary to the law of nature?
“It is progress that has been achieved by humankind.”
Delving deeper into the discussion, I would like to share some words my father once told
me. He suggested that we should interpret the teachings of the spirits in a certain way. He said,
”We love our family because we have yet to grasp the true essence of love.” Let’s take a moment
to understand his intention and contemplate his message. He believed that our ultimate goal
is to learn to love all beings in the universe with pure and unconditional love. However, since
we may not be capable or ready to do so, we begin by learning and practising love within our
own families. Gradually, we expand our deﬁnition of family, and in doing so, our circle of love
grows larger. This is the approach I personally embrace, and I ﬁnd that my family is constantly
expanding in a beautiful way.
Before we slightly shift the direction of our conversation, I would like to bring attention to
question 697, which highlights that marriage is a human construct and, as such, is subject to
change.
697. Is the binding nature of marriage a law of nature, or is it only dictated by human law?
“It is a human law that contradicts the law of nature. Human laws change, while natural law
is constant.”
Another perspective to consider when considering marriage is to view it as a business part-
nership. Like in a business, honesty and a shared vision are essential for the relationship’s
success. Unfortunately, ﬁnancial stability also plays a signiﬁcant role in this equation. Many
relationships crumble due to cash-ﬂow issues, leading to constant arguments and insurmount-
able stress. This scenario parallels the challenges startups face, where the lack of funds often
leads to the dissolution of the founders’ partnership.
In both cases, the importance of ﬁnancial stability cannot be underestimated. Just as a
business requires a solid ﬁnancial foundation to thrive, a marriage needs ﬁnancial security to
sustain itself. Money-related disagreements can strain even the strongest of bonds, causing rifts
that are diﬃcult to mend. It is crucial for couples to address their ﬁnancial situation openly
and honestly, working together to ﬁnd practical solutions and build a secure future.
Furthermore, the analogy between marriage and a business partnership extends beyond
ﬁnancial considerations. Similar to the need for eﬀective communication, collaboration, and
goal alignment in business, these qualities are vital for a harmonious marital relationship.
Just as successful business partners rely on each other’s strengths, couples must leverage their
individual strengths and support one another to achieve shared objectives.

metadata.file_name: Exploring the Depths of Human Existence.pdf
Exploring the Depths of Human Existence.pdf

__data__.text:
4.3. GENDER AND SEX 35
By recognizing the parallels between marriage and business, we gain valuable insights into
the dynamics of a successful partnership. It emphasizes the importance of transparency, trust,
and ﬁnancial responsibility in fostering a solid and lasting bond. Couples who approach their
relationship with a business mindset can better navigate challenges, make informed decisions,
and work together towards a prosperous future.
4.3 Gender and sex
Following our discussion on marriage, it is natural to delve into the topics of gender and sex.
Sex is a term used to categorize individuals based on their biological characteristics, typically
as male or female. On the other hand, gender is a socially constructed role, much like marital
status, that inﬂuences how individuals are perceived and expected to behave within a given
society.
It may seem natural to associate marriage with the union of two beings of opposite sexes,
considering that it has traditionally been seen as a means of procreation, as discussed in the
previous section. However, with the recognition that there are now alternative ways to bring
children into the world, this requirement is no longer absolute. As we come together as a
family unit to enhance our chances of survival, it becomes crucial to form groups that promote
harmony and compatibility, irrespective of the speciﬁc sex compositions involved.
According to The Spirits’ Book, the population of males and females is intentionally very
similar, which is used as an argument against polygamy. However, if we consider even a basic
understanding of statistics, such as the law of large numbers, we can anticipate that when there
are only two options with equal probabilities, repeated experiments will result in a distribution
that is very similar for both outcomes. For instance, if we ﬂip a coin, we know it has a 50%
chance of landing on heads and a 50% chance of landing on tails. If we toss the coin ten times,
the distribution could be eight tails and two heads, but if we repeat this process 100 times, it
will approach a much closer 50/50 split in outcomes. Considering the vast population of nearly
2 billion people on our planet, the distribution of males and females is expected to be close to
or around a 50/50 split.
In statistics, the law of large numbers reinforces the notion that as the sample size increases,
the observed frequencies of diﬀerent outcomes converge towards their theoretical probabilities.
This principle allows us to understand how seemingly random events, such as the distribution of
males and females in a population, can exhibit a stable and predictable pattern when observed
on a larger scale. By applying this statistical concept, we can better appreciate why the male-
to-female ratio tends to be relatively balanced across a substantial population.
As a society, we are evolving in our understanding of gender and granting ourselves the
apparent freedom to determine the social roles we individually choose to fulﬁl. As explored in
the preceding chapter, I refer to this as ”apparent free will” because it is a natural progression
in which we adapt to meet the needs of our species. Moreover, if Artiﬁcial Intelligence (AI)

metadata.file_name: Exploring the Depths of Human Existence.pdf
Exploring the Depths of Human Existence.pdf

__data__.text:
36 CHAPTER 4. SOCIAL CONSTRUCTS
were to become the dominant species on our planet, the discussion surrounding gender or sex
would likely become irrelevant.
Social laws concerning gender and equity are continuously evolving to align with our chang-
ing beliefs, serving as evidence of our societal progress. In a future where children may be born
through laboratory means, the formation of families will no longer be bound to traditional
methods. Sexual intercourse may primarily be pursued for pleasure, as it is already becoming
the case in many instances. Our relationships and interactions will no longer be solely driven
by the intention of procreation, allowing for a broader understanding and experience of human
sexuality.
4.4 Racism
Why do we feel the need to label and categorise? Is it merely a tool to aid communication
and assign names to things? Sometimes, labels carry profound meanings and divisions that we
create to assert control. As a species, we are renowned for our ability to collaborate in large
groups, but what deﬁnes the scale of ”large”? It ultimately depends on the resources available
for us to share. Our survival instinct drives us to be self-centred, as we discussed in the previous
chapter. However, our genetic makeup also instils a sense of care and concern for those who
are similar to us, including our children, more so than for others. This instinctual bias can help
explain the existence of racist behaviours and attitudes.
Fortunately, with the advancements in technology, we are witnessing increasing racial mix-
ing, and it is hopeful that in the future, we will embrace a uniﬁed human race. However, it
remains uncertain which will happen ﬁrst: our collective transformation into a single race or
the potential demise of our species at the hands of a more advanced civilization, such as AI.
During my childhood, I held onto the belief that discovering extraterrestrial life would unite
us as humans and transcend racial divisions. While progress has been made in this regard,
there is still much work to be done. Cultural change within a society takes time, just as it
takes time for beings to acquire suﬃcient knowledge to understand that we are essentially a
compilation of information and that the external appearance does not alter the intrinsic con-
tent. Our diﬀerences in physical attributes simply facilitate better adaptation and survival in
speciﬁc geographic regions.
It is indeed an observation rooted in our natural instincts that the one who initiates an attack
is often driven by fear. This pattern can be observed not only in the animal kingdom but also
in human behaviour. A bully, for instance, tends to target individuals who are physically or
mentally vulnerable as a means to mask their own insecurities. Jealousy can also fuel bullying
behaviour or be a catalyst for racist attitudes. These instincts and emotions can contribute to
a cycle of aggression and discrimination. Understanding these underlying dynamics can help us
address the root causes of such behaviours and work towards a more empathetic and inclusive
society.

Exploring the Depths of Human Existence.pdf

__data__.text:
4.4. RACISM 37
While fear can certainly be a contributing factor to the deeply ingrained social construct
of racism, it is important to recognize that racism is a multifaceted issue inﬂuenced by various
historical, systemic, and cultural factors. It is not solely driven by fear alone. Racism has
been perpetuated through power dynamics, institutional biases, and the historical legacy of
colonization and oppression.
One aspect to consider is the historical context in which racial prejudices emerged. It is
true that some individuals with lighter skin may have felt threatened by the physical strength
or cultural diﬀerences of those with darker skin. This fear may have led to the dissemination
of stereotypes and falsehoods to create division and exploit marginalized racial groups.
Similarly, the existence of jokes and stereotypes about certain physical attributes, such as
blond hair, can be rooted in jealousy or a desire to mock what is perceived as socially desirable.
However, it is important to note that these examples are just a small part of the broader
complexities of racism, and the motivations behind such actions can vary signiﬁcantly among
individuals.
To truly understand and address racism, we must delve deeper into its systemic and struc-
tural roots, recognizing the historical injustices, power imbalances, and institutional biases that
perpetuate inequality. By acknowledging these broader factors, we can work towards disman-
tling racism and fostering a more inclusive and equitable society.
